text:
- So Vijay, thank you
for joining us today.
- Thank you for having me.

- Can you start off and
maybe tell us a little bit
about yourself and your company?

- Yeah, I'm Vijay Chittoor,
co-founder and CEO at Blueshift.

Blueshift is an intelligent
customer engagement platform.
Our customers are consumer brands

and we help them
understand their consumers,
their customers really well,
and engage with them intelligently,
deliver personalized interactions
at every point in the customer journey.
- Oh that's great, so I understand you use
a lot of artificial intelligence in this.
- We do.

So I think like the genesis
of Blueshift, you know,
I started this company
with two other co-founders back in 2014.

And when we thought about
the opportunity here,
we started looking at our own experience.
We had previously worked at an AI company,

which got acquired by Walmart
and became Walmart Labs,

and then started a consumer
brand called Mertado,

which got acquired by Groupon
and became Groupon Goods.

And what we started seeing
at companies like Groupon
and Walmart was that the customer journey
is becoming much more fragmented.

And at the same time,
you and I as consumers,

we are leaving behind
a much richer footprint

about who we are through clues
on websites, mobile apps,
all of our interactions

and so many different touch
points in the customer journey

is just starting to add
up to really reflect
what we want in the moment,
what we want over a long period of time.

And the struggle we saw it
in our previous experiences
prior to founding Blueshift was that
if you are a marketing team,

if you're a customer engagement
team at one of these brands,
taking advantage of all that data,
trying to understand what customers want
and being able to react to that

and being able to do that
across many different channels

was a humongous task,
very complex for marketing teams,
which are not technical by nature.
And the question we asked ourselves was,

can we use AI to simplify
all this complexity?
Can we actually help marketers understand,
automate, personalize at scale using AI?

And that's kind of what got
us started on that journey

and we've been using a lot
of different forms of AI.
Excited to talk more about that.
- Yeah so maybe you could start off
and just tell us a little bit about

what is the technology
stack that you're using?

Because you know, I'm talking
to so many customers right now

that want to get started with
AI and generative AI of course.

And a lot of them are just
kind of stuck where to begin.
So what advice would you give for them?

- I think the first,
specifically in our domain
as we think about the nature of AI,

it all starts with, first,
having a large amount of data.

So in our case, the data is
all about first party data

of consumers which is
organized at a per brand level.
So essentially each of our customers
has a large repository of data,

which they may or may not have
been tracking historically,
but with Blueshift we make it easy

for them to get started on
that data unification journey,

which often, I'm sure you're
finding this in your experience

is one of the key steps
to graduating towards AI.

So I think the step one is
really about like having
that rich data, well organized,
being able to capture that in real time,
being able to, you know, unify that data.

But then second, I think
when you think about
sort of the advice we give to everyone
starting on that AI journey

is really to think about
the end customer first.

And in our case, when we
think about the customer,

you know, we really think
about how can you use AI
to deliver personalized interactions
to the end consumer.

And for us, a lot of that means
thinking about customer AI.
And when you think about customer AI,

it's really about taking
that customer data,
the first party data we talked about

and translating that into
the who, what, when and where
of how to engage with a customer.

So when you think about, you
know, traditional marketing,

which is often very manual,
not driven by AI, you start,
you know, making maybe flat decisions

about who to target
for a certain campaign,
what offers to show them,
when to sort of reach out to the customer

and which channel or where
should you engage with them.

And if you think about it in
the apps with the, you know,
in a world which doesn't involve AI,

when you're making these
decisions manually,
you are oversimplifying it quite a bit
and lumping a bunch of customers together

and you're trying to say,
"Well this whole segment,

let's just target them
with this one offer."
But the reality is that people,
the end consumers are unique individuals

and they need to be
responded to differently.

And what AI does really well
is even when the human market
is sleeping in that moment,
it's able to make that decision
at an individual customer level

and make millions of these
decisions in aggregate, right?

And I think that's the
kind of decisioning engine,
and that's the kind of decisioning power,

the power personalization
that AI gives you.

So when we advise people on
how to get to that AI journey,
start by organizing that data.
Second thing, customer first,
think about the use cases,

but then be able to leverage
sort of the advantage of AI

that it can, you know,
make decisions at scale,
it can personalize to an individual
and transform your end customer experience
with those elements in mind.

- Yeah absolutely. Yeah
that's a great point.
You know, it's really about personalizing
the experience, right?
I mean AI as a manual process,
it would be just too laborious, right?
To be able to do that for any human to do,
even if they were working 24 hours, right?
- That's exactly right, yeah.
- But with AI, presumably it gets it right
more often as well

because it's drawing more
different data points.
- That's exactly right.

And I think you touched on
something important there

where you're thinking about
the end customer journey.

And if you think about
it, like a lot of people

have been talking about
how customer journeys

have become much more complex
in today's digital world

where so many different
touch points have emerged.

And in that complex,
because of that complexity,
there are millions of permutations
of the customer journey, right?

So in some ways, I think the
customer engagement problem
for today is really about nurturing
each customer's self-directed journey

because every customer is
automatically on a journey
with the brand.
So how do you recognize the journey
that each individual's on.

How can you be helpful
to them in that moment,
and how can you do that at scale?

And really that's kind of
where AI kind of comes in
and helps everyone.
So when we work with marketers,

I think marketers are very
good at being storytellers.
But today the challenge
is how do you take the kernel of the story

but individualize it
across all these different
self-projected journeys?
And that's where I think marketers
can partner really well with AI.

And that's been a very
powerful partnership.
- Yeah, that sounds amazing.
So let me ask you this,
what is the role of humans in all of this?

- So I think the humans are
the core creative element
behind all of this.

They're also the strategic
drivers behind all of this.

So in some ways, I think
when I think about sort of,
you know, a lot of automation technology,
the first wave of automation technology

essentially made it harder for
humans to be more strategic
and be more creative.

Because I think, you know,
a lot of that automation
was conditional and if this then that
kind of rule-based automation.
And a lot of times, you know, marketers

and other, you know, departments
across the enterprise

ended up just pushing a
lot of buttons and knobs
and, you know, it took the creativity
and strategic thinking out of their jobs.
And I think with the new wave of AI
which is truly driving real automation,
where you don't have to be sitting around
pressing if this and that kind of buttons,

you're actually, you know,
being challenged more

and empowered more to
deliver the strategic value
and the creativity, you can actually now
really think about the stories
you want to tell to your end customers

and use technology as an assistant
to deliver those at scale
and not be bogged down by kind of fighting
against your technology in some ways.

So in that sense, like AI
has unlocked the potential

a lot of humans and we are
very excited about that.

- Yeah so like kind of a more
of a co-creator relationship
than like replacing the human altogether.
- That's exactly right.

And the co-creator analogy
in some ways, like, you know,
sometimes we talk about sort of this idea

that everyone, you
know, becomes an editor.
You know, and in a literal sense
like people who are now writing
are able to get first drafts quickly
and are spending more time editing.
But in a more strategic level,

you start thinking about the
work of, you know, humans.

Everyone I think in every
role across every department

in the enterprise is getting
elevated to that level
of an editor and they don't have to,

they'll do less of the grunt
work of maybe coming up

with the initial drafts
and the initial writing.
- Yeah less of that undifferentiated work.
and more that's kind of personalization
and kind of final touches.
- That's exactly right.

- Yeah so let's talk
about the skillset needed
to create a company like this,

because most of the enterprises
I work with, you know,
they all want to work with AI,
but it's a very hard skill to recruit for
because, you know, data scientists
and anyone in the field of AI
is very hard to recruit nowadays.
They're very valuable.

So what has been your
approach to recruiting

and getting this talent
within your organization?
- That's a great question.
I think part of it is recruiting, right?

But part of it's also
setting the right culture.
So when we think of the recruiting, right?
I think we've been fortunate from day one
to have AI talent in the company.

My co-founder Manyam serves
as our chief AI officer,
and he has done some very impressive work.

You know, dating back to
days when the, you know,
AI was not as much a buzzword.

So I think it's great to
start with someone like that
and build sort of the foundation
of the team in the right way.

So there's definitely
a lot about, you know,

looking for the right
skill set and the talent,

but then equally I think
the culture is important.

So you have to kind of
set the right framework

for the whole company, not
just the machine learning

and the AI engineers,
but the whole company

to sort of be able to
leverage these technologies
and to be able to take them to customers
and sort of make the customer successful.
So when we think about culture,

we talk about five core
culture values at Blueshift.

Those five values, when we
take sort of the first letter,
they form the word “Morph.”

So the first one, “M”, is
for make new mistakes.

And that's kind of a
surprising one a little bit

because why would you ask
someone to make mistakes?

But the key part is sort
of the making new mistakes,
which is all about learning rapidly,
being able to try things out,

but also having that
constant learning culture
and element of curiosity and learning.

So we start with that because
I think that's very critical,
especially with new technologies like AI.

Second, we talk about obsessing
over customer success.
So that's the “O” in “Morph.”

And again, I think when
you think about technology
for it to be really valuable,

you really have to have
the end customer in mind.
So again, obsessing over that,

whether it's our technology
teams or even if our marketing
and sales and customer success team,

everyone's kind of obsessing
with that customer success.
“R” is for raise the bar.
So we challenge ourselves
to be the best version of ourselves
and you know, truly thinking about
what's the best innovation
that we can deliver to our customers.
So that's about raising the bar.
The fourth one, “P”, is for play as one team.
So a lot of this innovation for us
to make our customers successful,

we have to play as one team
across the entire company.

Starting with the folks
who are developing this

all the way to, you know,
frontline facing, you know,
customer teams and so on.

And finally the last one, “H”,
is for have fun, seriously.

So that's, you know,
that's just acknowledging

that all of this work is, you
know, it's going to be hard,
but you know, we'll create a culture

where we make it enjoyable
for everyone to come to work
and have as much fun building this
and enjoying the journey
as much as looking at the destination.
- Well you know, it sounds like
an incredible company to work for.
It sounds almost Amazonian.
- Thank you. No that's a good compliment.

Obviously you guys have built
a great culture at Amazon
and it's great to partner
with like-minded companies like Amazon.

- You mentioned before, I
think it was the “M” right?
Make mistakes.
That might sound scary to some people.

How do you ensure that you
reduce the cost of failure?

So those mistakes, you
know, aren't catastrophic?
- Yeah, I think that's absolutely key.

So I think when we talk
about make mistakes,
we talk about make new mistakes,
and it's much more of the emphasis

on the learning culture
within the company.
But equally we are talking about obsessing
over customer success.

So customer, there are a lot
of use cases that we serve
for customers which are mission critical.

And again, like as we are
grounded in sort of this idea
of obsessing on customer success,

you have to take anything
that's mission critical
very, very seriously.
And that's not the area
where you want to be making mistakes.

But, you know, balancing
sort of that innovation,

which can happen behind
the scenes as we develop,

but then taking the final
developed product in a form

which truly meets the bar for
obsessing on customer success.

That's kind of the two things
that we have to strive for.

And on that note, I think
it's great to partner with,
you know, fantastic companies like Amazon

because we rely on Amazon for
a lot of our infrastructure.

It needs to be reliable,
it needs to be performant,
needs to have low latency, all of that.
And I think that's, you know,

the mindset we take when
we think about sort of
delivering products to our customers
and obsessing over that customer success.

There are things where, you
know, you want to kind of,
when you're prototyping things,
when you are building things internally,
you do want to make mistakes quickly.
You want to kind of have a culture
where everyone wants to experiment,

but you also want to
have a culture which is,
you know, cognizant of the time
when it's not okay to make mistakes
and is very grounded in that notion
of obsessing our customer success
and making sure that, you know,
we are taking our responsibility
to the end customer very, very seriously.
- Yeah, absolutely.

Any other advice you have
on talent development?
Because again, I can't stress this enough,
every organization in the world right now
is trying to hire AI and data scientists.
- Yep.

- You have any other
secrets you could share?
- I think a lot of it comes down to
some of the aspects we talked about before
about building the right culture.
One aspect of it I would double click on

is really just the idea that
you have to start embracing

that innovation within your
own organization as well,

and we encourage, like
kind of from early on,
we encourage our teams to be,

you know, consumers of
technology and you know,

use that for automation,
use that for, you know,
speeding up a lot of their own work.
So our teams across many departments
have been early adopters of AI technology
in some form or the other.

And that's another
thing that can make sure

that we are attracting
the right kind of folks

who are touching this
technology themselves

for their own use cases as
they are building it for,
you know, for other customers as well.

- Have there been any
challenges along the way?
And if so, how did you overcome them?
- That's a great question.
I think, you know, as we are taking

some of this innovative
technology to market

there have been a couple of
interesting challenges over time

that we have now tackled
specifically around AI.

So the first one I would
say is really about
making AI trustworthy and explainable

because it's being deployed
in enterprise situations.
And our customers want to make sure

that the experience they're
delivering to the end consumer
is consistent with their brand.

And it's, you know, is
a smooth personalized,
you know, value added interaction.

So when you're going and
telling the enterprise

that the AI is kind of
making all these decisions,
how do you convince like,

you know, the customer experience
team, the marketing team,
that the AI is making the right decisions
because they would not be able to audit

each and every one by
looking at it manually,

because that would almost
defeat the purpose.
So really I think a lot of the ways
we try to solve this challenge,
and we've been very successful at that now

is about making the AI
explainable at multiple levels.
So how do you ensure

that a non-technical
marketer, for example,
could come into the Blueshift platform

and understand sort of
the effects of the AI
before it is deployed?

And to understand it, you
create a UI where you know,
somebody who just doesn't, you know,

fully follow all the
different parameters of the AI
can still understand enough about it
by understanding whether the model itself
like is one of high confidence
by understanding the nature of data

that went into maybe
the modeling itself,
the features that got extracted

and were used by maybe
looking at, you know,
user interfaces that explain how this AI

might have made a decision
for a hypothetical customer
in a certain segment, for example.

And I think building all
of that into the, you know,
into the applications user interface

has been a key thing
in being able to deploy
that AI with confidence.
And that's something I would urge everyone

sort of who is, you know,
taking AI technologies to market
to think about where you want the humans
to be able to collaborate with that AI

and in order for them to
collaborate successfully,
they need that AI to be explainable,
intuitive, interpretable.

- So in other words, the
AI will give an answer,

but it needs to explain
how it got to that answer?
- To a large extent yes.

Or that answer should feel so
intuitive that it feels right.

And you know, there should
be enough evidence that,

you know, without looking
at millions of decisions,

you should be able to be
convinced that, you know,

it's still doing the right
thing for the end customer.
- Got it.

So one of the things
everybody wants to know
is what does the future hold, right?
I mean, nobody has a crystal ball,

but if you were to guess two,
three years into the future,

how do you see AI and maybe
more specifically generative AI

shaping this in terms
of customer experience?
- That's a great question.

So when you look at the
first wave of generative AI
over the last few months,

we've been hearing so
much about generative AI
and everyone's talking about
it's taken the whole world by storm.

I think a lot of the
initial use cases for gen AI
have been about creating content
in more and more variations
and being able to reduce the complexity,
the time to create new content.

And if you think about the
world of customer experience,
which you touched on historically,

for teams that are trying to
deliver a customer experience,
there's been a big content bottleneck

in order to produce the
right content to, you know,

personalize each and
every interaction, right?
If you think about sort of millions
of personalized interactions,

how do you create millions
of pieces of content?

So in some ways, the first
thing that gen AI has done
is to eliminate or at least reduce
the bottleneck on content creation
in many variations of the same content.

But where is going to go next
is really about combining

that gen AI with what
we call a customer AI
to deliver true personalization.

So what customer AI would
do is really predict
what each individual wants
or what variation of content might appeal
to each and every individual.

And what gen AI could
do is to actually create

all of that content in
real time or near real time
and be able to make that available.

So simple examples of that
could be to take a promotion
that a brand sends out through an SMS,

can the copy be different
for each and every customer?
Can that be informed not just by sentiment

and you know, things
like that which are easy
for generative AI to manipulate,
but also by customer AI,
which really understands
which offer the customer is interested in.

And when you bring those
two elements together,

we feel that'll unlock the
next level of the holy grail
of personalization in some ways.

So we are very excited about
the future where gen AI
and customer AI come together
to deliver great customer experiences.

- So is there any advice that
you would give out to folks

who are out there, you know,
they're maybe in the beginning

of their AI journey from
someone who's been at it
for quite some time.

We have a lot of people
who are starting right now.
What is some of the top things
that you would advise that they consider?
- So if you think about it in a...

there's a lot of latent
potential in companies.
There's a lot of latent knowledge,

there's a lot of,
you know, latent data,
which could be used to deliver, you know,
value to end consumers.

So how do you unlock the
value of all of that?

You know, I think traditionally
brands have, you know,
started with human driven efforts.

They have then done some bit
of digital transformation to,

you know, use some technology
to start unlocking the value.
But really with AI,
everyone in the enterprise is now enabled

to actually deliver that
transformational value
to end customers.

And you know, if you start
thinking from that lens,

you start thinking
about how you would redo
your entire strategy, your processes.
If you had to build everything AI first,

some of this would need
processes to be reinvented.
- Yeah so you mentioned something,

I think you kind of alluded
to the kind of democratization
of this technology, right?
Giving it to the hands
of all the people in your organization
or more people in your organization.

And also what I'm hearing is
take the data you already have,
which is probably going largely unused,

and use this technology to
unlock the insights in that data.
- That's exactly right.
Yeah, that's exactly right.
The democratization.
Because this technology is becoming mature

to a point where non-technical
users will be able to use it.

And as that happens at scale
across many enterprises,

it just unlocks tremendous
enterprise value.
So thinking about, you know,

how that can be the biggest
driver for your growth,

by getting this technology
in the hands of, you know,
customer facing teams, into the hands

of a lot of other non-technical
functions in your company
is going to be the key to to scaling.
- That's great advice.
Vijay, thank you so much for joining us.
- Thank you. Thank you for having me.
